001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003import squidpony.ArrayTools;
004
005import java.io.Serializable;
006import java.util.*;
007
008import static squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools.intBitsToFloat;
009
010/**
011 * A wrapper class for working with random number generators in a more friendly way.
012 * Implements {@link IRNG}, which covers most of the API surface, but RNG implements
013 * a decent amount of additional methods. You should consider if your code needs
014 * these additional methods, and if not you should use IRNG as the type for when you
015 * need some random number generator.
016 * <p>
017 * Includes methods for getting values between two numbers and for getting
018 * random elements from a collection or array. There are methods to shuffle
019 * a collection and to get a random ordering that can be applied as one shuffle
020 * across multiple collections, such as via {@link OrderedMap#reorder(int...)},
021 * {@link ArrayTools#reorder(ArrayList, int...)}, and so on. You can construct
022 * an RNG with all sorts of RandomnessSource implementations, and choosing them
023 * is usually not a big concern because the default works very well. If you target
024 * GWT, then it is suggested that you use {@link GWTRNG} instead of RNG; both
025 * implement {@link IRNG}, which is enough for most usage across SquidLib, but
026 * GWTRNG is optimized heavily for better performance on GWT, even returning long
027 * values faster than implementations that natively do their math on longs. It has
028 * worse performance on 64-bit PCs and mobile devices, but should also have better
029 * performance on 32-bit PCs and mobile devices.
030 * <br>
031 * But if you do want advice on what RandomnessSource to use... {@link DiverRNG}
032 * is the default, and is the fastest generator that passes most tests and can
033 * produce all 64-bit values, and though relative to many of the others it has a
034 * significantly shorter period (the amount of random numbers it will go through
035 * before repeating the sequence), this almost never matters in games, and is
036 * primarily relevant for massively-parallel scientific programs. DiverRNG has a
037 * period of {@code pow(2, 64)} as opposed to {@link XoRoRNG}'s
038 * {@code pow(2, 128) - 1}, or {@link LongPeriodRNG}'s {@code pow(2, 1024) - 1}.
039 * {@link LightRNG} is a solid choice and a former default RandomnessSource;
040 * additional features of LightRNG are exposed in {@link MoonwalkRNG} and using
041 * MoonwalkRNG is recommended if you need unusual features like skipping backwards
042 * in a random number sequence, taking a result of a nextLong() call and reversing
043 * it to get the state that produced it, or calculating the distance in number of
044 * nextLong() calls between two results of nextLong() calls. LightRNG is a
045 * StatefulRandomness, which lets it be used in {@link StatefulRNG}, and so is
046 * DiverRNG, but LightRNG is also a {@link SkippingRandomness}, which means you can
047 * leap forward or backwards in its sequence very efficiently (DiverRNG is not a
048 * SkippingRandomness). {@link ThrustAltRNG} provides similar qualities to LightRNG,
049 * and is one of the fastest generators here, but can't produce all possible 64-bit
050 * values (possibly some 32-bit values as well); it was the default at one point so
051 * you may want to keep compatibility with some versions by specifying ThrustAltRNG.
052 * The defaults have changed in the past as issues are found in various generators;
053 * LightRNG has high quality all-around but is slower than the other defaults,
054 * ThrustAltRNG can't produce all results, LinnormRNG passed tests in an earlier
055 * version of the PractRand test suite but now fails in the current version, and now
056 * the default is DiverRNG, which shares the known issue of LightRNG and LinnormRNG
057 * that it can't produce the same result twice from {@link #nextLong()} until the
058 * generator exhausts its period and repeats its output from the beginning.
059 * For most cases, you should decide between DiverRNG, ThrustAltRNG, LightRNG,
060 * LongPeriodRNG, MiniMover64RNG, and XoshiroStarPhi32RNG based on your priorities.
061 * Some tasks are better solved by using a different class, usually {@link GWTRNG},
062 * which can always be serialized on GWT to save its state easily and is usually the
063 * fastest substitute for RNG on that platform. DiverRNG is the best if you want high
064 * speed, very good quality of randomness, and expect to generate a reasonable quantity
065 * of numbers for a game (less than 18446744073709551616 numbers) without any single
066 * results being impossible. LightRNG is the second-best at the above criteria, but is
067 * the best option if you need an RNG that can skip backwards or jump forwards without
068 * incurring speed penalties. LongPeriodRNG is best if you for some reason need a massive
069 * amount of random numbers (as in, ten quintillion would be far too little) or want to
070 * split up such a large generator into unrelated subsequences. XoshiroStarPhi32RNG is
071 * best if GWT is a possible target but you either need to generate more than
072 * 18446744073709551616 numbers (but less than 340282366920938463463374607431768211455
073 * numbers) or you need to ensure that each 128-bit chunk of output is unique; if GWT is
074 * a target but those specific needs don't matter, use GWTRNG. ThrustAltRNG and
075 * MiniMover64RNG are both faster than DiverRNG usually (MiniMover64RNG is the fastest),
076 * but because they are unable to generate some outputs, that may make them a poor choice
077 * for some usage (ThrustAltRNG also has some bias toward specific numbers and produces
078 * them more frequently, but not frequently enough to make it fail statistical tests, and
079 * ThrustAltRNG can skip around in its output sequence like LightRNG).
080 * <br>
081 * There are many more RandomnessSource implementations! You might want significantly less
082 * predictable random results, which  {@link IsaacRNG} can provide, along with a
083 * large period. The quality of {@link PermutedRNG} is also good, usually, and it
084 * has a sound basis in PCG-Random, an involved library with many variants on its
085 * RNGs.
086 * <br>
087 * There may be reasons why you would want a random number generator that uses 32-bit
088 * math instead of the more common 64-bit math, but using a 32-bit int on desktop and
089 * Android won't act the same as that same 32-bit int on GWT. Since GWT is stuck with
090 * JavaScript's implementation of ints with doubles, overflow (which is needed for an
091 * RNG) doesn't work with ints as expected, but does with GWT's implementation of longs.
092 * If targeting GWT, you should probably consider {@link GWTRNG} or {@link SilkRNG},
093 * which would be used in place of this class and have a similar API. You can instead
094 * choose a RandomnessSource that is efficient on GWT; {@link Lathe32RNG} is
095 * significantly faster at producing int values on GWT than any long-based generator,
096 * and will produce the same results on GWT as on desktop or Android (not all 32-bit
097 * generators do this). {@link Starfish32RNG} goes one step further than Lathe32RNG at
098 * an even distribution, and has better quality, but is slightly slower; it is also used
099 * internally by GWTRNG. While Lathe32RNG can produce all ints over the course of its
100 * period, it will produce some pairs of ints, or longs, more often than others and will
101 * never produce some longs. Starfish32RNG will produce all longs but one.
102 * {@link Oriole32RNG} and {@link XoshiroStarPhi32RNG} are also GWT-safe, but other
103 * generators that were thought to be GWT-friendly are not. {@link PintRNG} is a
104 * GWT-unsafe generators with other uses, but should not be used on GWT. All other
105 * RandomnessSources use longs, and so will be slower than the recommended Starfish32RNG
106 * or Lathe32RNG on GWT, but probably are much faster on 64-bit JREs.
107 * @author Eben Howard - http://squidpony.com - howard@squidpony.com
108 * @author Tommy Ettinger
109 * @author smelC
110 */
111public class RNG extends AbstractRNG implements Serializable {
112
113        protected RandomnessSource random;
114        protected Random ran;
115
116    private static final long serialVersionUID = 2352426757973945105L;
117
118
119    /**
120     * Default constructor; uses {@link DiverRNG}, which is of high quality, but low period (which rarely matters
121     * for games), and has excellent speed, tiny state size, and natively generates 64-bit numbers.
122     * <br>
123     * Previous versions of SquidLib used different implementations, including {@link LightRNG}, {@link ThrustAltRNG},
124     * {@link LinnormRNG}, and {@link MersenneTwister}. You can still use one of these by instantiating one of those
125     * classes and passing it to {@link #RNG(RandomnessSource)}, which may be the best way to ensure the same results
126     * across versions.
127     */
128    public RNG() {
129        this(new DiverRNG());
130    }
131
132    /**
133     * Default constructor; uses {@link DiverRNG}, which is of high quality, but low period (which rarely matters
134     * for games), and has excellent speed, tiny state size, and natively generates 64-bit numbers. The seed can be
135     * any long, including 0.
136     * @param seed any long
137     */
138    public RNG(long seed) {
139        this(new DiverRNG(seed));
140    }
141
142    /**
143     * String-seeded constructor; uses a platform-independent hash of the String (it does not use String.hashCode,
144     * instead using {@link CrossHash#hash64(CharSequence)}) as a seed for {@link DiverRNG}, which is of high quality,
145     * but low period (which rarely matters for games), and has excellent speed, tiny state size, and natively generates
146     * 64-bit numbers.
147     */
148    public RNG(CharSequence seedString) {
149        this(new DiverRNG(CrossHash.hash64(seedString)));
150    }
151
152    /**
153     * Uses the provided source of randomness for all calculations. This constructor should be used if an alternate
154     * RandomnessSource other than DiverRNG is desirable, such as to keep compatibility with earlier SquidLib
155     * versions that defaulted to MersenneTwister, LightRNG, ThrustAltRNG, or LinnormRNG.
156     * <br>
157     * If the parameter is null, this is equivalent to using {@link #RNG()} as the constructor.
158     * @param random the source of pseudo-randomness, such as a LightRNG or LongPeriodRNG object
159     */
160    public RNG(RandomnessSource random) {
161        this.random = (random == null) ? new DiverRNG() : random;
162    }
163
164    /**
165     * A subclass of java.util.Random that uses a RandomnessSource supplied by the user instead of the default.
166     *
167     * @author Tommy Ettinger
168     */
169    public static class CustomRandom extends Random {
170
171        private static final long serialVersionUID = 8211985716129281944L;
172        private final RandomnessSource randomnessSource;
173
174        /**
175         * Creates a new random number generator. This constructor uses
176         * a DiverRNG with a random seed.
177         */
178        public CustomRandom() {
179            randomnessSource = new DiverRNG();
180        }
181
182        /**
183         * Creates a new random number generator. This constructor uses
184         * the seed of the given RandomnessSource if it has been seeded.
185         *
186         * @param randomnessSource a way to get random bits, supplied by RNG
187         */
188        public CustomRandom(RandomnessSource randomnessSource) {
189            this.randomnessSource = randomnessSource;
190        }
191
192        /**
193         * Generates the next pseudorandom number. Subclasses should
194         * override this, as this is used by all other methods.
195         * <p>
196         * <p>The general contract of {@code next} is that it returns an
197         * {@code int} value and if the argument {@code bits} is between
198         * {@code 1} and {@code 32} (inclusive), then that many low-order
199         * bits of the returned value will be (approximately) independently
200         * chosen bit values, each of which is (approximately) equally
201         * likely to be {@code 0} or {@code 1}. The method {@code next} is
202         * implemented by class {@code Random} by atomically updating the seed to
203         * <pre>{@code (seed * 0x5DEECE66DL + 0xBL) & ((1L << 48) - 1)}</pre>
204         * and returning
205         * <pre>{@code (int)(seed >>> (48 - bits))}.</pre>
206         *
207         * This is a linear congruential pseudorandom number generator, as
208         * defined by D. H. Lehmer and described by Donald E. Knuth in
209         * <i>The Art of Computer Programming,</i> Volume 3:
210         * <i>Seminumerical Algorithms</i>, section 3.2.1.
211         *
212         * @param bits random bits
213         * @return the next pseudorandom value from this random number
214         * generator's sequence
215         * @since 1.1
216         */
217        @Override
218        protected int next(int bits) {
219            return randomnessSource.next(bits);
220        }
221
222        /**
223         * Returns the next pseudorandom, uniformly distributed {@code long}
224         * value from this random number generator's sequence. The general
225         * contract of {@code nextLong} is that one {@code long} value is
226         * pseudorandomly generated and returned.
227         *
228         * @return the next pseudorandom, uniformly distributed {@code long}
229         * value from this random number generator's sequence
230         */
231        @Override
232        public long nextLong() {
233            return randomnessSource.nextLong();
234        }
235    }
236
237    /**
238     * @return a Random instance that can be used for legacy compatibility
239     */
240    public Random asRandom() {
241        if (ran == null) {
242            ran = new CustomRandom(random);
243        }
244        return ran;
245    }
246    /**
247     * Returns the average of a number of randomly selected numbers from the
248     * provided range, with min being inclusive and max being exclusive. It will
249     * sample the number of times passed in as the third parameter.
250     * <p>
251     * The inclusive and exclusive behavior is to match the behavior of the
252     * similar method that deals with floating point values.
253     * <p>
254     * This can be used to weight RNG calls to the average between min and max.
255     *
256     * @param min     the minimum bound on the return value (inclusive)
257     * @param max     the maximum bound on the return value (exclusive)
258     * @param samples the number of samples to take
259     * @return the found value
260     */
261    public int betweenWeighted(int min, int max, int samples) {
262        int sum = 0;
263        for (int i = 0; i < samples; i++) {
264            sum += between(min, max);
265        }
266
267        return Math.round((float) sum / samples);
268    }
269
270    /**
271     * Returns a random element from the provided array and maintains object
272     * type.
273     *
274     * @param <T>   the type of the returned object
275     * @param array the array to get an element from
276     * @return the randomly selected element
277     */
278    @Override
279    public <T> T getRandomElement(T[] array) {
280        if (array.length < 1) {
281            return null;
282        }
283        return array[nextInt(array.length)];
284    }
285
286    /**
287     * Given a {@link List} l, this selects a random element of l to be the first value in the returned list l2. It
288     * retains the order of elements in l after that random element and makes them follow the first element in l2, and
289     * loops around to use elements from the start of l after it has placed the last element of l into l2.
290     * <br>
291     * Essentially, it does what it says on the tin. It randomly rotates the List l.
292     * <br>
293     * If you only need to iterate through a collection starting at a random point, the method getRandomStartIterable()
294     * should have better performance. This was GWT incompatible before GWT 2.8.0 became the version SquidLib uses; now
295     * this method works fine with GWT.
296     *
297     * @param l   A {@link List} that will not be modified by this method. All elements of this parameter will be
298     *            shared with the returned List.
299     * @param <T> No restrictions on type. Changes to elements of the returned List will be reflected in the parameter.
300     * @return A shallow copy of {@code l} that has been rotated so its first element has been randomly chosen
301     * from all possible elements but order is retained. Will "loop around" to contain element 0 of l after the last
302     * element of l, then element 1, etc.
303     */
304    public <T> List<T> randomRotation(final List<T> l) {
305        final int sz = l.size();
306        if (sz == 0)
307            return new ArrayList<>(0);
308
309                /*
310                 * Collections.rotate should prefer the best-performing way to rotate l,
311                 * which would be an in-place modification for ArrayLists and an append
312                 * to a sublist for Lists that don't support efficient random access.
313                 */
314        List<T> l2 = new ArrayList<>(l);
315        Collections.rotate(l2, nextInt(sz));
316        return l2;
317    }
318
319    /**
320     * Get an Iterable that starts at a random location in list and continues on through list in its current order.
321     * Loops around to the beginning after it gets to the end, stops when it returns to the starting location.
322     * <br>
323     * You should not modify {@code list} while you use the returned reference. And there'll be no
324     * ConcurrentModificationException to detect such erroneous uses.
325     *
326     * @param list A list <b>with a constant-time {@link List#get(int)} method</b> (otherwise performance degrades).
327     * @return An {@link Iterable} that iterates over {@code list} but start at
328     * a random index. If the chosen index is {@code i}, the iterator
329     * will return:
330     * {@code list[i]; list[i+1]; ...; list[list.length() - 1]; list[0]; list[i-1]}
331     */
332    public <T> Iterable<T> getRandomStartIterable(final List<T> list) {
333        final int sz = list.size();
334        if (sz == 0)
335            return new ArrayList<>(0);
336
337                /*
338                 * Here's a tricky bit: Defining 'start' here means that every Iterator
339                 * returned by the returned Iterable will have the same iteration order.
340                 * In other words, if you use more than once the returned Iterable,
341                 * you'll will see elements in the same order every time, which is
342                 * desirable.
343                 */
344        final int start = nextInt(sz);
345
346        return new Iterable<T>() {
347            @Override
348            public Iterator<T> iterator() {
349                return new Iterator<T>() {
350
351                    int next = -1;
352
353                    @Override
354                    public boolean hasNext() {
355                        return next != start;
356                    }
357
358                    @Override
359                    public T next() {
360                        if (next == start)
361                            throw new NoSuchElementException("Iteration terminated; check hasNext() before next()");
362                        if (next == -1)
363                                        /* First call */
364                            next = start;
365                        final T result = list.get(next);
366                        if (next == sz - 1)
367                                        /*
368                                         * Reached the list's end, let's continue from the list's
369                                         * left.
370                                         */
371                            next = 0;
372                        else
373                            next++;
374                        return result;
375                    }
376
377                    @Override
378                    public void remove() {
379                        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Remove is not supported from a randomStartIterable");
380                    }
381
382                    @Override
383                    public String toString() {
384                        return "RandomStartIterator at index " + next;
385                    }
386                };
387            }
388        };
389    }
390
391    /**
392     * Shuffle an array using the Fisher-Yates algorithm and returns a shuffled copy.
393     * GWT-compatible since GWT 2.8.0, which is the default if you use libGDX 1.9.5 or higher.
394     * <br>
395     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
396     *
397     * @param elements an array of T; will not be modified
398     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
399     * @return a shuffled copy of elements
400     */
401    @Override
402    public <T> T[] shuffle(final T[] elements) {
403        final int size = elements.length;
404        final T[] array = Arrays.copyOf(elements, size);
405        for (int i = size; i > 1; i--) {
406            swap(array, i - 1, nextIntHasty(i));
407        }
408        return array;
409    }
410
411    /**
412     * Shuffles an array in-place using the Fisher-Yates algorithm.
413     * If you don't want the array modified, use {@link #shuffle(Object[], Object[])}.
414     * <br>
415     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
416     *
417     * @param elements an array of T; <b>will</b> be modified
418     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
419     * @return elements after shuffling it in-place
420     */
421    @Override
422    public <T> T[] shuffleInPlace(T[] elements) {
423        final int size = elements.length;
424        for (int i = size; i > 1; i--) {
425            swap(elements, i - 1, nextIntHasty(i));
426        }
427        return elements;
428    }
429
430    /**
431     * Shuffle an array using the Fisher-Yates algorithm. If possible, create a new array or reuse an existing array
432     * with the same length as elements and pass it in as dest; the dest array will contain the shuffled contents of
433     * elements and will also be returned as-is.
434     * <br>
435     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
436     *
437     * @param elements an array of T; will not be modified
438     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
439     * @param dest     Where to put the shuffle. If it does not have the same length as {@code elements}, this will use the
440     *                 randomPortion method of this class to fill the smaller dest.
441     * @return {@code dest} after modifications
442     */
443    @Override
444    public <T> T[] shuffle(T[] elements, T[] dest) {
445        if (dest.length != elements.length)
446            return randomPortion(elements, dest);
447        System.arraycopy(elements, 0, dest, 0, elements.length);
448        shuffleInPlace(dest);
449        return dest;
450    }
451
452    /**
453     * Shuffles a {@link Collection} of T using the Fisher-Yates algorithm and returns an ArrayList of T.
454     * <br>
455     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
456     * @param elements a Collection of T; will not be modified
457     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
458     * @return a shuffled ArrayList containing the whole of elements in pseudo-random order.
459     */
460    @Override
461    public <T> ArrayList<T> shuffle(Collection<T> elements) {
462        return shuffle(elements, null);
463    }
464
465    /**
466     * Shuffles a {@link Collection} of T using the Fisher-Yates algorithm. The result
467     * is allocated if {@code buf} is null or if {@code buf} isn't empty,
468     * otherwise {@code elements} is poured into {@code buf}.
469     * <br>
470     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
471     * @param elements a Collection of T; will not be modified
472     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
473     * @param buf a buffer as an ArrayList that will be filled with the shuffled contents of elements;
474     *            if null or non-empty, a new ArrayList will be allocated and returned
475     * @return a shuffled ArrayList containing the whole of elements in pseudo-random order.
476     */
477    @Override
478    public <T> ArrayList<T> shuffle(Collection<T> elements, /*@Nullable*/ ArrayList<T> buf) {
479        final ArrayList<T> al;
480        if (buf == null || !buf.isEmpty())
481            al = new ArrayList<>(elements);
482        else {
483            al = buf;
484            al.addAll(elements);
485        }
486        final int n = al.size();
487        for (int i = n; i > 1; i--) {
488            Collections.swap(al, nextInt(i), i - 1);
489        }
490        return al;
491    }
492    /**
493     * Shuffles a Collection of T items in-place using the Fisher-Yates algorithm.
494     * This only shuffles List data structures.
495     * If you don't want the array modified, use {@link #shuffle(Collection)}, which returns a List as well.
496     * <br>
497     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
498     *
499     * @param elements a Collection of T; <b>will</b> be modified
500     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
501     * @return elements after shuffling it in-place
502     */
503    @Override
504    public <T> List<T> shuffleInPlace(List<T> elements) {
505        final int n = elements.size();
506        for (int i = n; i > 1; i--) {
507            Collections.swap(elements, nextInt(i), i - 1);
508        }
509        return elements;
510    }
511
512
513    /**
514     * Generates a random permutation of the range from 0 (inclusive) to length (exclusive).
515     * Useful for passing to OrderedMap or OrderedSet's reorder() methods.
516     *
517     * @param length the size of the ordering to produce
518     * @return a random ordering containing all ints from 0 to length (exclusive)
519     */
520    @Override
521    public int[] randomOrdering(int length) {
522        if (length <= 0)
523            return new int[0];
524        return randomOrdering(length, new int[length]);
525    }
526
527    /**
528     * Generates a random permutation of the range from 0 (inclusive) to length (exclusive) and stores it in
529     * the dest parameter, avoiding allocations.
530     * Useful for passing to OrderedMap or OrderedSet's reorder() methods.
531     *
532     * @param length the size of the ordering to produce
533     * @param dest   the destination array; will be modified
534     * @return dest, filled with a random ordering containing all ints from 0 to length (exclusive)
535     */
536    @Override
537    public int[] randomOrdering(int length, int[] dest) {
538        if (dest == null) return null;
539
540        final int n = Math.min(length, dest.length);
541        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
542            dest[i] = i;
543        }
544        for (int i = n - 1; i > 0; i--) {
545            final int r = nextIntHasty(i+1),
546                    t = dest[r];
547            dest[r] = dest[i];
548            dest[i] = t;
549        }
550        return dest;
551    }
552
553    /**
554     * Gets a random portion of a Collection and returns it as a new List. Will only use a given position in the given
555     * Collection at most once; does this by shuffling a copy of the Collection and getting a section of it.
556     *
557     * @param data  a Collection of T; will not be modified.
558     * @param count the non-negative number of elements to randomly take from data
559     * @param <T>   can be any non-primitive type
560     * @return a List of T that has length equal to the smaller of count or data.length
561     */
562    public <T> List<T> randomPortion(Collection<T> data, int count) {
563        return shuffle(data).subList(0, Math.min(count, data.size()));
564    }
565
566    /**
567     * Gets a random subrange of the non-negative ints from start (inclusive) to end (exclusive), using count elements.
568     * May return an empty array if the parameters are invalid (end is less than/equal to start, or start is negative).
569     *
570     * @param start the start of the range of numbers to potentially use (inclusive)
571     * @param end   the end of the range of numbers to potentially use (exclusive)
572     * @param count the total number of elements to use; will be less if the range is smaller than count
573     * @return an int array that contains at most one of each number in the range
574     */
575    public int[] randomRange(int start, int end, int count) {
576        if (end <= start || start < 0)
577            return new int[0];
578
579        int n = end - start;
580        final int[] data = new int[n];
581
582        for (int e = start, i = 0; e < end; e++) {
583            data[i++] = e;
584        }
585
586        for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) {
587            final int r = i + nextInt(n - i), t = data[r];
588            data[r] = data[i];
589            data[i] = t;
590        }
591        final int[] array = new int[Math.min(count, n)];
592        System.arraycopy(data, 0, array, 0, Math.min(count, n));
593        return array;
594    }
595
596    /**
597     * Generates a random float with a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely)
598     * approach -1f and 1f, but not go beyond those bounds. This is similar to {@link Random#nextGaussian()} in that it
599     * uses a curved distribution, but it is not the same. The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and
600     * is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near -1f or 1f. It cannot produce values greater than or equal to 1f, or
601     * less than -1f, but it can produce -1f.
602     * @return a deterministic float between -1f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive), that is very likely to be close to 0f
603     */
604    public float nextCurvedFloat() {
605        final long start = random.nextLong();
606        return   (intBitsToFloat((int)start >>> 9 | 0x3F000000)
607                + intBitsToFloat((int) (start >>> 41) | 0x3F000000)
608                + intBitsToFloat(((int)(start ^ ~start >>> 20) & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
609                + intBitsToFloat(((int) (~start ^ start >>> 30) & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
610                - 3f);
611    }
612
613
614    /**
615     * Gets a random double between 0.0 inclusive and 1.0 exclusive.
616     * This returns a maximum of 0.9999999999999999 because that is the largest double value that is less than 1.0 .
617     *
618     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 0.9999999999999999 (inclusive)
619     */
620    @Override
621    public double nextDouble() {
622        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1p-53;
623        //this is here for a record of another possibility; it can't generate quite a lot of possible values though
624        //return Double.longBitsToDouble(0x3FF0000000000000L | random.nextLong() >>> 12) - 1.0;
625    }
626
627    /**
628     * Gets a random float between 0.0f inclusive and 1.0f exclusive.
629     * This returns a maximum of 0.99999994 because that is the largest float value that is less than 1.0f .
630     *
631     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and 0.99999994f (inclusive)
632     */
633    @Override
634    public float nextFloat() {
635        return random.next(24) * 0x1p-24f;
636    }
637
638    /**
639     * Get a random bit of state, interpreted as true or false with approximately equal likelihood.
640     * This may have better behavior than {@code rng.next(1)}, depending on the RandomnessSource implementation; the
641     * default DiverRNG will behave fine, as will LightRNG and ThrustAltRNG (these all use similar algorithms), but
642     * the  normally-high-quality XoRoRNG will produce very predictable output with {@code rng.next(1)} and very good
643     * output with {@code rng.nextBoolean()}. This is a known and considered flaw of Xoroshiro128+, the algorithm used
644     * by XoRoRNG, and a large number of generators have lower quality on the least-significant bit than the most-
645     * significant bit, where this method only checks the most-significant bit.
646     * @return a random boolean.
647     */
648    @Override
649    public boolean nextBoolean() {
650        return nextLong() < 0L;
651    }
652
653    /**
654     * Get a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE to Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).
655     *
656     * @return a 64-bit random long.
657     */
658    @Override
659    public long nextLong() {
660        return random.nextLong();
661    }
662
663    /**
664     * Returns a random non-negative integer between 0 (inclusive) and the given bound (exclusive),
665     * or 0 if the bound is 0. The bound can be negative, which will produce 0 or a negative result.
666     * Uses an aggressively optimized technique that has some bias, but mostly for values of
667     * bound over 1 billion. This method is no more "hasty" than {@link #nextInt(int)}, but it is a little
668     * faster than that method because this avoids special behavior for when bound is negative.
669     * <br>
670     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
671     *
672     * @param bound the outer bound (exclusive), can be negative or positive
673     * @return the found number
674     */
675    public int nextIntHasty(final int bound) {
676        return (int) ((bound * (random.nextLong() & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
677    }
678
679    /**
680     * Generates random bytes and places them into the given byte array, modifying it in-place.
681     * The number of random bytes produced is equal to the length of the byte array. Unlike the
682     * method in java.util.Random, this generates 8 bytes at a time, which can be more efficient
683     * with many RandomnessSource types than the JDK's method that generates 4 bytes at a time.
684     * <br>
685     * Adapted from code in the JavaDocs of {@link Random#nextBytes(byte[])}.
686     * <br>
687     * @param  bytes the byte array to fill with random bytes; cannot be null, will be modified
688     * @throws NullPointerException if the byte array is null
689     */
690    public void nextBytes(final byte[] bytes) {
691        for (int i = 0; i < bytes.length; )
692            for (long r = random.nextLong(), n = Math.min(bytes.length - i, 8); n-- > 0; r >>>= 8)
693                bytes[i++] = (byte) r;
694    }
695
696    /**
697     * Get a random integer between Integer.MIN_VALUE to Integer.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).
698     *
699     * @return a 32-bit random int.
700     */
701    @Override
702    public int nextInt() {
703        return random.next(32);
704    }
705
706    /**
707     * Get up to 32 bits (inclusive) of random output; the int this produces
708     * will not require more than {@code bits} bits to represent.
709     *
710     * @param bits an int between 1 and 32, both inclusive
711     * @return a random number that fits in the specified number of bits
712     */
713    @Override
714    public int next(int bits) {
715        return random.next(bits);
716    }
717
718    public RandomnessSource getRandomness() {
719        return random;
720    }
721
722    public void setRandomness(RandomnessSource random) {
723        this.random = random;
724    }
725
726    /**
727     * Creates a copy of this RNG; it will generate the same random numbers, given the same calls in order, as this RNG
728     * at the point copy() is called. The copy will not share references with this RNG.
729     *
730     * @return a copy of this RNG
731     */
732    public RNG copy() {
733        return new RNG(random.copy());
734    }
735
736    /**
737     * Generates a random 64-bit long with a number of '1' bits (Hamming weight) equal on average to bitCount.
738     * For example, calling this with a parameter of 32 will be equivalent to calling nextLong() on this object's
739     * RandomnessSource (it doesn't consider overridden nextLong() methods, where present, on subclasses of RNG).
740     * Calling this with a parameter of 16 will have on average 16 of the 64 bits in the returned long set to '1',
741     * distributed pseudo-randomly, while a parameter of 47 will have on average 47 bits set. This can be useful for
742     * certain code that uses bits to represent data but needs a different ratio of set bits to unset bits than 1:1.
743     * <br>
744     * This method is deprecated because it really only finds usage in GreasedRegion, so it has been moved there and
745     * made so it can take any RandomnessSource as a parameter, including any IRNG or RNG.
746     *
747     * @param bitCount an int, only considered if between 0 and 64, that is the average number of bits to set
748     * @return a 64-bit long that, on average, should have bitCount bits set to 1, potentially anywhere in the long
749     * @deprecated see the version in GreasedRegion, {@link GreasedRegion#approximateBits(RandomnessSource, int)}
750     */
751    @Deprecated
752    public long approximateBits(int bitCount) {
753        if (bitCount <= 0)
754            return 0L;
755        if (bitCount >= 64)
756            return -1L;
757        if (bitCount == 32)
758            return random.nextLong();
759        boolean high = bitCount > 32;
760        int altered = (high ? 64 - bitCount : bitCount), lsb = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(altered);
761        long data = random.nextLong();
762        for (int i = lsb << 1; i <= 16; i <<= 1) {
763            if ((altered & i) == 0)
764                data &= random.nextLong();
765            else
766                data |= random.nextLong();
767        }
768        return high ? ~(random.nextLong() & data) : (random.nextLong() & data);
769    }
770
771    /**
772     * Gets a somewhat-random long with exactly 32 bits set; in each pair of bits starting at bit 0 and bit 1, then bit
773     * 2 and bit 3, up to bit 62 and bit 3, one bit will be 1 and one bit will be 0 in each pair.
774     * <br>
775     * Not exactly general-use; meant for generating data for GreasedRegion. This is deprecated in favor of the version
776     * in GreasedRegion.
777     * @return a random long with 32 "1" bits, distributed so exactly one bit is "1" for each pair of bits
778     * @deprecated See {@link GreasedRegion#randomInterleave(RandomnessSource)} for where this will be moved
779     */
780    @Deprecated
781    public long randomInterleave() {
782        long bits = nextLong() & 0xFFFFFFFFL, ib = ~bits & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
783        bits |= (bits << 16);
784        ib |= (ib << 16);
785        bits &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
786        ib &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
787        bits |= (bits << 8);
788        ib |= (ib << 8);
789        bits &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
790        ib &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
791        bits |= (bits << 4);
792        ib |= (ib << 4);
793        bits &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
794        ib &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
795        bits |= (bits << 2);
796        ib |= (ib << 2);
797        bits &= 0x3333333333333333L;
798        ib &= 0x3333333333333333L;
799        bits |= (bits << 1);
800        ib |= (ib << 1);
801        bits &= 0x5555555555555555L;
802        ib &= 0x5555555555555555L;
803        return (bits | (ib << 1));
804    }
805
806    /**
807     * Gets the minimum random long between 0 and {@code bound} generated out of {@code trials} generated numbers.
808     * Useful for when numbers should have a strong bias toward zero, but all possible values are between 0, inclusive,
809     * and bound, exclusive.
810     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be negative or positive
811     * @param trials how many numbers to generate and get the minimum of
812     * @return the minimum generated long between 0 and bound out of the specified amount of trials
813     */
814    public long minLongOf(final long bound, final int trials)
815    {
816        long value = nextSignedLong(bound);
817        for (int i = 1; i < trials; i++) {
818            value = Math.min(value, nextSignedLong(bound));
819        }
820        return value;
821    }
822    /**
823     * Gets the maximum random long between 0 and {@code bound} generated out of {@code trials} generated numbers.
824     * Useful for when numbers should have a strong bias away from zero, but all possible values are between 0,
825     * inclusive, and bound, exclusive.
826     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be negative or positive
827     * @param trials how many numbers to generate and get the maximum of
828     * @return the maximum generated long between 0 and bound out of the specified amount of trials
829     */
830    public long maxLongOf(final long bound, final int trials)
831    {
832        long value = nextSignedLong(bound);
833        for (int i = 1; i < trials; i++) {
834            value = Math.max(value, nextSignedLong(bound));
835        }
836        return value;
837    }
838

842     * and bound, exclusive.
843     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be negative or positive
844     * @param trials how many numbers to generate and get the minimum of
845     * @return the minimum generated int between 0 and bound out of the specified amount of trials
846     */
847    public int minIntOf(final int bound, final int trials)
848    {
849        int value = nextSignedInt(bound);
850        for (int i = 1; i < trials; i++) {
851            value = Math.min(value, nextSignedInt(bound));
852        }
853        return value;
854    }

939
940    @Override
941    public String toString() {
942        return "RNG with Randomness Source " + random;
943    }
944
945    @Override
946    public boolean equals(Object o) {
947        if (this == o) return true;
948        if (!(o instanceof RNG)) return false;
949
950        RNG rng = (RNG) o;
951
952        return random.equals(rng.random);
953    }
954
955    @Override
956    public int hashCode() {
957        return 31 * random.hashCode();
958    }
959
960    /**
961     * Gets a random portion of data (an array), assigns that portion to output (an array) so that it fills as much as
962     * it can, and then returns output. Will only use a given position in the given data at most once; uses a Feistel
963     * Network to accomplish this without allocations. Internally, makes 2 calls to {@link #nextInt()}, regardless of
964     * the data being randomized.
965     * <br>
966     * Uses approximately the same code as {@link LowStorageShuffler}, but without any object or array allocations.
967     *
968     * @param data   an array of T; will not be modified.
969     * @param output an array of T that will be overwritten; should always be instantiated with the portion length
970     * @param <T>    can be any non-primitive type.
971     * @return output, after {@code Math.min(output.length, data.length)} unique items have been put into it from data
972     */
973    @Override
974    public <T> T[] randomPortion(T[] data, T[] output) {
975        final int length = data.length, n = Math.min(length, output.length);
976        // calculate next power of 4.  Needed since the balanced Feistel network needs
977        // an even number of bits to work with
978        int pow4 = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo(length);
979        if((pow4 & 0x55555554) == 0)
980            pow4 = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo(pow4);
981        pow4--;
982        // calculate our left and right masks to split our indices for the Feistel network
983        final int halfBits = Integer.bitCount(pow4) >>> 1;
984        final int rightMask = pow4 >>> halfBits;
985        final int leftMask = pow4 ^ rightMask;
986        final int key0 = nextInt(), key1 = nextInt();
987        int index = 0;
988        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
989            int shuffleIndex;
990            // index is the index to start searching for the next number at
991            while (index <= pow4)
992            {
993                // break our index into the left and right half
994                int left = (index & leftMask) >>> halfBits;
995                int right = (index & rightMask);
996                // do 2 Feistel rounds
997                int newRight = left ^ (LowStorageShuffler.round(right, key0) & rightMask);
998                left = right;
999                right = newRight;
1000                newRight = left ^ (LowStorageShuffler.round(right, key1) & rightMask);
1001                shuffleIndex = right << halfBits | newRight;
1002                index++;
1003
1004                // if we found a valid index, return it!
1005                if (shuffleIndex < length) {
1006                    output[i] = data[shuffleIndex];
1007                    break;
1008                }
1009            }
1010        }
1011        return output;
1012    }
1013
1014
1015    /**
1016     * Gets a random double between 0.0 inclusive and 1.0 inclusive.
1017     *
1018     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (inclusive)
1019     */
1020    public double nextDoubleInclusive()
1021    {
1022        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1.0000000000001p-53;
1023    }
1024
1025    /**
1026     * This returns a random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (inclusive). The value for outer can be positive
1027     * or negative. Because of how math on doubles works, there are at most 2 to the 53 values this can return for any
1028     * given outer bound, and very large values for outer will not necessarily produce all numbers you might expect.
1029     *
1030     * @param outer the outer inclusive bound as a double; can be negative or positive
1031     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (inclusive)
1032     */
1033    public double nextDoubleInclusive(final double outer) {
1034        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1.0000000000001p-53 * outer;
1035    }
1036
1037    /**
1038     * Gets a random float between 0.0f inclusive and 1.0f inclusive.
1039     *
1040     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and 1f (inclusive)
1041     */
1042    public float nextFloatInclusive() {
1043        return random.next(24) * 0x1.000002p-24f;
1044    }
1045
1046    /**
1047     * This returns a random float between 0.0f (inclusive) and outer (inclusive). The value for outer can be positive
1048     * or negative. Because of how math on floats works, there are at most 2 to the 24 values this can return for any
1049     * given outer bound, and very large values for outer will not necessarily produce all numbers you might expect.
1050     *
1051     * @param outer the outer inclusive bound as a float; can be negative or positive
1052     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and outer (inclusive)
1053     */
1054    public float nextFloatInclusive(final float outer) {
1055        return random.next(24) * 0x1.000002p-24f * outer;
1056    }
1057
1058
1059
1060
1061
1062    /**
1063     * Gets a random Coord that has x between 0 (inclusive) and width (exclusive) and y between 0 (inclusive)
1064     * and height (exclusive). This makes one call to randomLong to generate (more than) 31 random bits for
1065     * each axis, and should be very fast. Remember that Coord values are cached in a pool that starts able to
1066     * hold up to 255 x and 255 y for positive values, and the pool should be grown with the static method
1067     * Coord.expandPool() in order to efficiently use larger Coord values. If width and height are very large,
1068     * greater than 100,000 for either, this particular method may show bias toward certain positions due to
1069     * the "hasty" technique used to reduce the random numbers to the given size, but because most maps in
1070     * tile-based games are relatively small, this technique should be fine.
1071     * <br>
1072     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
1073     *
1074     * @param width  the upper bound (exclusive) for x coordinates
1075     * @param height the upper bound (exclusive) for y coordinates
1076     * @return a random Coord between (0,0) inclusive and (width,height) exclusive
1077     */
1078    public Coord nextCoord(int width, int height) {
1079        final long n = random.nextLong();
1080        return Coord.get((int) ((width * (n >>> 33)) >> 31), (int) ((height * (n & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31));
1081    }
1082
1083    /**
1084     * Use that to get random cells in a rectangular map.
1085     *
1086     * @param width  The map's width (bounds the x-coordinate in returned coords).
1087     * @param height The map's height (bounds the y-coordinate in returned coords).
1088     * @param size   The number of elements in the returned iterable or anything
1089     *               negative for no bound (in which case the iterator is infinite, it's
1090     *               up to you to bound your iteration).
1091     * @return An iterable that returns random cells in the rectangle (0,0)
1092     * (inclusive) .. (width, height) (exclusive).
1093     */
1094    public Iterable<Coord> getRandomCellsIterable(final int width, final int height, final int size) {
1095        return new Iterable<Coord>() {
1096            @Override
1097            public Iterator<Coord> iterator() {
1098                return new Iterator<Coord>() {
1099
1100                    /**
1101                     * The number of elements returned so far
1102                     */
1103                    int returned;
1104
1105                    @Override
1106                    public boolean hasNext() {
1107                        return size < 0 || returned < size;
1108                    }
1109
1110                    @Override
1111                    public Coord next() {
1112                        if (!hasNext())
1113                            throw new NoSuchElementException();
1114                        returned++;
1115                        return nextCoord(width, height);
1116                    }
1117
1118                    @Override
1119                    public void remove() {
1120                        throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1121                    }
1122                };
1123            }
1124        };
1125    }
1126
1127    /**
1128     * Gets an array of unique Coords, from (startX,startY) inclusive to (startX+width,startY+height) exclusive, in a
1129     * random order, with the array containing {@code width * height} items.
1130     *
1131     * @param startX the inclusive starting x position
1132     * @param startY the inclusive starting y position
1133     * @param width  the width of the space to place Coords in, extending from startX
1134     * @param height the height of the space to place Coords in, extending from startY
1135     * @return an array containing {@code width * height} Coord items in random order, inside the given bounds
1136     */
1137    public Coord[] getRandomUniqueCells(final int startX, final int startY, final int width, final int height) {
1138        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0)
1139            return new Coord[0];
1140        return getRandomUniqueCells(startX, startY, width, height, new Coord[width * height]);
1141    }
1142
1143    /**
1144     * Gets an array of unique Coords, from (startX,startY) inclusive to (startX+width,startY+height) exclusive, in a
1145     * random order, with the array containing {@code Math.min(width * height, size)} items. If size is less than width
1146     * times height, then not all Coords in the space will be used.
1147     *
1148     * @param startX the inclusive starting x position
1149     * @param startY the inclusive starting y position
1150     * @param width  the width of the space to place Coords in, extending from startX
1151     * @param height the height of the space to place Coords in, extending from startY
1152     * @param size   the size of the array to return; only matters if it is smaller than {@code width * height}
1153     * @return an array containing {@code Math.min(width * height, size)} Coord items in random order, inside the given bounds
1154     */
1155    public Coord[] getRandomUniqueCells(final int startX, final int startY, final int width, final int height,
1156                                        final int size) {
1157        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0 || size <= 0)
1158            return new Coord[0];
1159        return getRandomUniqueCells(startX, startY, width, height, new Coord[Math.min(width * height, size)]);
1160    }
1161
1162    /**
1163     * Assigns to dest an array of unique Coords, from (startX,startY) inclusive to (startX+width,startY+height)
1164     * exclusive, in a random order, with dest after this is called containing the lesser of {@code width * height} or
1165     * {@code dest.length} items. This will not allocate a new array for dest, but will create a temporary int array for
1166     * handling the shuffle.
1167     *
1168     * @param startX the inclusive starting x position
1169     * @param startY the inclusive starting y position
1170     * @param width  the width of the space to place Coords in, extending from startX
1171     * @param height the height of the space to place Coords in, extending from startY
1172     * @param dest   a Coord array that will be modified to contain randomly-ordered Coords, but will not be resized
1173     * @return dest, now with up to its first {@code width * height} items assigned to random Coords inside the given bounds
1174     */
1175    public Coord[] getRandomUniqueCells(final int startX, final int startY, final int width, final int height,
1176                                        final Coord[] dest) {
1177        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0 || dest == null || dest.length <= 0)
1178            return dest;
1179        int[] o = randomOrdering(width * height);
1180        for (int i = 0; i < o.length && i < dest.length; i++) {
1181            dest[i] = Coord.get(startX + o[i] % width, startY + o[i] / width);
1182        }
1183        return dest;
1184    }
1185
1186    /**
1187     * Returns this RNG in a way that can be deserialized even if only {@link IRNG}'s methods can be called.
1188     * @return a {@link Serializable} view of this RNG; always {@code this}
1189     */
1190    @Override
1191    public Serializable toSerializable() {
1192        return this;
1193    }
1194}
